ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to critically analyze a film and about the political context of Weimar Germany. This was my first time taking a film class, and I had a great time watching these fascinating early German films while learning about the advances in film technology that made them possible, the situation in the German film industry at the time, and the popular and critical response to the narratives and acting.
Learned a lot about Weimar history, along with the popular film movements at the time. Learned how to appreciate silent films.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Our conversations in class sometimes felt a little slow, but I enjoyed the structure of a weekly film and reading response. It meant that the workload stayed consistent throughout the semester, there is no midterm or final exam/paper, and I received lots of feedback about my writing that I could implement as the semester went on. I noticed a real improvement in my reading responses over the course of the semester as I became more familiar with film terms and noticed recurring patterns and themes between the films.

Strengths are the movies and the course structure. The weekly reading responses over writing a final paper was so great. It meant that everyone had to stay engaged throughout the course without being overworked.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to students who are interested in any combination of German history, Holocaust and Nazi history, the early/mid 20th century, questions of modernity, the emergence of new technologies, and film as a medium. I learned so much about the cultural context of film production and am going to take these insights into my other courses. It's not that much work, but the weekly reading responses do require some thinking and time. I loved being able to watch interesting movies for a homework assignment, so the reading responses didn't feel like a burden, but you do need to account for a solid few hours of time outside of class each week.

Absolutely! If you are a film major looking to talk about great films, this is the class for you. If you have never taken a film class before, the subject matter might be daunting at first, but prof Hagens makes it extremely approachable. One of the best seminars Ive taken at Yale!
